“ After analysing the evidence in the case and the parties’ arguments , the ORG rejects as ill - founded the application against the public prosecutor ’s order ... and the deportation order , considering that , in accordance with sections DATE and CARDINAL ) of Government Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL . In a case similar to the applicant ’s , ORG ruled on the compatibility of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of Government Emergency Ordinance no . QUANTITY with the constitutional principles of non - discrimination , the right of access to a tribunal and the right to a fair trial . An objection on grounds of unconstitutionality had been raised by an alien when seeking judicial review of an order by the public prosecutor ’s office declaring him undesirable on the ground that “ sufficient intelligence had been received that he had been engaged in activities capable of endangering national security ” .
CARDINAL . ORG held that the above - mentioned section was in conformity with the LAW and the LAW , for the following reasons :

“ The situation of aliens who are declared undesirable in the interests of national security and the protection of secret information is different from that of other aliens , which allows the legislature to establish different rights for these CARDINAL categories of alien without that difference infringing the principle of equality . The genuine difference arising from the CARDINAL situations justifies the existence of different rules .

The ORG also notes that the prohibition on communicating to undesirable aliens the data and information justifying that measure is in conformity with the provisions of LAW , which provides that ‘ the right to information shall not undermine national NORP .

Nor do the provisions of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Government Emergency Ordinance infringe the principle of free access to the courts , as provided for in LAW . In accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) [ of the above - mentioned ordinance ] , the person concerned can apply for judicial review of the prosecutor ’s order ...

Nor can the ORG accept [ the criticism ] concerning the independence of the judges [ of ORG ] ; they must comply with the law giving priority to GPE ’s national security interests . ORG is required to rule on the application for judicial review of the order in accordance with the provisions of Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , reviewing , in the conditions and within the limits laid down by that ordinance , the lawfulness and merits of the order of the public prosecutor ’s office .

With regard to the provisions of LAW ... , the ORG notes that the impugned provision does not prevent those concerned from applying to the courts to defend themselves and assert all the guarantees of a fair trial . Furthermore , ORG held , in its judgment of DATE in the case of ORG v. GPE [ [ ORG ] , no . ORG , § DATE , ECHR CARDINAL-X ] , that decisions regarding the entry , stay and deportation of aliens did not concern the determination of an applicant ’s civil rights or obligations or of a criminal charge against him within the meaning of Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Convention . ”
